summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to defense counsel in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, transmitting a batch of discovery materials. The materials include records related to Alfredo Rodriguez, flight records from Insured Aircraft Title Service, and records from Interlochen, all designated as confidential under a protective order.

events.title: Discovery Production to Maxwell Defense
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office produces a batch of discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team, including records on Alfredo Rodriguez, flight logs, and Interlochen records.

events.title: Protective Order Issued
events.description: A protective order was issued in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, governing the handling of confidential discovery materials.

keyFacts: The prosecution produced discovery materials including records related to Alfredo Rodriguez, who was an employee of Jeffrey Epstein.
Flight records from Insured Aircraft Title Service were included in the production, likely pertaining to Epstein's private aircraft.
Records from 'Interlochen' were produced; Interlochen is known as an arts academy, potentially relevant to the investigation's scope.
All produced materials were governed by a strict protective order, marked to avoid confusion with classified document markings.
The document confirms the ongoing discovery obligations of the government in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case as of November 2021.
